text: Effects of <extra_id_0> CD45 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on NF-kappa B . Implications for replication of HIV-1 .
Increased levels of replication of the HIV type 1 are observed after the activation of infected T cells through the TCR .
However , anti - <extra_id_0> CD45 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antibodies inhibit these effects in cells from infected individuals .
In this study , we examined interrelationships between <extra_id_0> CD45 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and HIV-1 further .

We measured effects on the HIV-1 LTR in T cell lines that were stimulated with antibodies against <extra_id_0> CD45 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and in those that lacked the expression of <extra_id_0> CD45 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on their surfaces .
First , anti - <extra_id_0> CD45 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antibodies did not affect basal but decreased activated levels of expression from the HIV-1 LTR .
Second , T cells , which lack <extra_id_0> CD45 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and can not signal via the TCR , supported higher levels of viral replication and gene expression .
This was due to the presence of active NF-kappa B complexes in the nucleus of <extra_id_0> CD45 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - T cells .
Additionally , infected T cells displayed lower levels of <extra_id_0> CD45 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on their surfaces .

text: Thus , <extra_id_0> CD45 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> plays an active role in the physiology of T cells and in the replication of HIV-1 .
